ca.ualberta.cmput301f13t13.storyhoard.local

Class Syncher

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.ualberta.cmput301f13t13.storyhoard.local.Syncher

  • public class Syncher
extends java.lang.Object
    Role: uses all of the manager classes to "sync" stories. For example, if a user downloads a story from the server, it must be saved into the database, and all of the images within its chapters must also be saved onto the SD card. This class takes care of updating story information locally and does so by using methods from the manager classes.

    Design Pattern: This class is a singleton, so only one instance of it will ever exist during the application's lifecycle.
    Author:
    Stephanie Gil

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static Syncher getInstance(Context context)
        Retrieves an instance of the Syncher class. Because it is a singleton, the same instance will always be returned.

        Example call:
        Syncher syncher = Syncher.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        Parameters:
        context - Can be an activity or application context.

      • syncStoryFromMemory

        public void syncStoryFromMemory(Story story)
        This method is for updating the database when the user modifies a story locally. So any changes to the story, including any changes to its chapters or the choices and media contained in those chapters will be updated in the database.

        Note that it doesn't always just update story information. If any object doesn't exist in the database, it will also be added.

        Example call:
        Syncher syncher = Syncher.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        Story myStory = new Story("title", "author", "description", "phoneId");
        syncher.syncStoryFromMemory(myStory);
        Parameters:
        story - Story object that is gotten locally you want to sync.

      • syncChapterParts

        public void syncChapterParts(Chapter chap)
        Given a chapter object, this method takes care of synching the parts of a chapter (media and choices). This means all its media and choices will either be inserted into the database if they don't exist, or will be updated if they exist. Any deletions to media will also by synched. Note that this ONLY updates the chapter parts, not the chapter's information itself (eg. chapter text, story id it belongs to).

        Example call:
        Assume "chap" is a chapter object that contains choices and media.
        Syncher syncher = Syncher.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        syncher.syncChapterParts(chap);
        Parameters:
        chap - Chapter object you want to sync.

      • syncStoryFromServer

        public void syncStoryFromServer(Story story)
        This method takes care of saving a story from the server into the database. This includes all the parts of a story (chapter, and choices and media belonging to the chapters). As well, it saves the bitmaps of all the images contained in its chapters to the SD card so the user who downloaded the story can use those images as well.

        Example call:
        Assume myStory is a story downloaded from the server (a story downloaded from the server will always have all of its components).

        Syncher syncher = Syncher.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        syncher.syncStoryFromServer(myStory);

        myStory has now been saved to the database, along with all chapters, media, and choices.
        Parameters:
        story - Story object that came from the server you want to save locally.

      • syncChaptersFromDb

        public java.util.ArrayList<Chapter> syncChaptersFromDb(java.util.UUID storyId)
        Syncs all the chapters of a story. This means retrieving every chapter of the given story id, and getting all the choices and medias that belong to it. This is usually when a story is about to get published onto the server (since a story needs to have all of its components before going on to the server). It is also used however when reading a story; all the chapters are first retrieved, so then each one can be displayed as the user reads on.

        Example call:
        UUID storyId = UUID.fromString("5231b533-ba17-4787-98a3-f2df37de2aD7");
        Parameters:
        storyId - The id of the story we want to get all the chapters from. Must be a UUID.
